comments.commentBody: You got that right!

Peggy,  P.T. Barnum said it all", There is a sucker born every minute." Welcome to Wonderland. This country is the land of suckers who believe everything snake-oil salesmen say. This is not good for Democracy.

@Peggy55408

Ron Johnson a pretty face???? Ugh!

Russ Feingold always won by attracting the votes of moderate Republicans. His vote for the ACA ended that--might be different today. We are all hoping he'll run again--perhaps for Governor.

Ms. Collins, I wish I could agree with you when you say that "We may not see her like again. Or, if one shows up, we may decide not to pay attention." Unfortunately, that statement id disproved by the fact that there are plenty of other Congresspeople who are just as crazy as Ms. Bachmann.

For example, Congressman Paul Broun (R-GA) rejects evolution, wants to repeal the 16th and 17th Amendments (which created the income tax and direct election of Senators, respectively), and calls the Civil War the "War of Yankee Aggression."

In Texas, Congressman Louie Gohmert rants about non-existent "terror babies" and "death panels," supports birther legislation, and was the only person in Congress to oppose the removal of the word "lunatic" from federal laws.

North Carolina has given us the shining beacon of crazy that is Congresswoman Virginia Foxx, who believes that ObamaCare poses a bigger threat to the US than terrorists, says she has no patience for people with large student loans, and claims that the murder of Matthew Shepard was not a hate crime.

The list could go on - Steve King (R-Iowa), Ron Paul, Ted Cruz (R-TX) also belong to the crazy caucus. Certainly, the fact that Rep. Bachmann will be leaving Congress is a victory for rationality and intelligence. But the truly unfortunate fact is that she just one of many know-nothing crazies that roam the halls of Congress.

www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236
Great article

Every few months I will read another article detailing the horror that is the Zimbabwe tragedy and I am saddened by the knowledge that the New York Times would print the racist words of a apologist. Today I came across this article that lays out in stark detail the terror brought upon the Zimbabwean people by Mugabe and his thugs.

http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/05/zimbabwe/fuller-text

AG Holder and DOJ are currently our #1 enemy of press freedom and civil liberties in general, an out-of-hand menace that qualifies both by any common-sense definition to be home-grown TERRORISTS. Holder, always with Obama guarding his back, had trampled on habeas corpus rights affecting detainees; worse perhaps, he is responsible, along with his Boss, for employing the Espionage Act against whistleblowers, more than the combined total of Obama's predecessors.

It's time to clean the Augean stables. Holder is a disgrace to the rule of law. And Obama, given his signature weapon, armed drones for targeted assassination, clearly stands in violation of international law--possessing, no doubt, spurious legitimation from the Office of Legal Counsel and Holder. Why the extreme SECRECY which characterizes the administration, unless of course for fear that policies and practices would be disclosed showing Obama to be a war criminal?

Good riddance to lawbreakers who cloak themselves in the mantle of the law. The shame here is that only Republicans--and for their own partisan reasons--seem concerned about press freedom. Where can the people turn for honest, disinterested government?
Right next to me with your flag waving proudly and a mouthful of Oreos.
My kids are pretty much never late to school, but I do serve them processed food and take-out about. So where does that put me on the "good parent who has his/her priorities straight" spectrum?
Right next to me with your flag waving proudly and a mouthful of Oreos.

He wasn't doing the taxes. He was doing the tax PREP. I thought it was strange on first reading that he was doing his own taxes at 4 am…why waste time doing his own taxes when it costs only what, $2000 - to have an accountant do it. I applaud him for not doing his own taxes. Smart choice in a world of limited time.

@ pediatricianX, agreed. Years ago, for a short time, I worked with a relatively small group whose tradition was to always eat lunch together. One female co-worker was obsessed with weight and dieting, and every lunch devolved into her banal monolog of what she "can" and what she "can't" eat (all while practically licking the Food section of the local paper). Here's one example I remember:

COWORKER: What are you eating for lunch? ME: Uh, minestrone soup. COWORKER: Are there noodles in there? Me: Uh, a few. COWORKER: Oh, well, I can't eat that!! ME: Uh, OK.

On and on went said self-absorbed, food-obsessed bore, who, all the while bemoaning her weight (while trumpeting her supposed self-dicipline) wore ill-judged, overly revealing clothing, particularly for the office. Unsurprisingly, of her 3 teenage children, 2 were very overweight and 1 looked waifish. Growing up listening to that, it's no surprise none were anywhere near the middle of the bell curve regarding weight.

PediatricianX, I love love love your prescription, "just have a life." Personally, I have too many mental and physical things to do during the day between my career, hitting the gym, and wrangling 3 little kids to get through it on little/no food, or give all my attention to resisting hunger. Similarly, I have too many things to do during the day to just "snack," or sit idly by and eat a bag of chips or the like! And those things are a lot more interesting to hear about than the fat in my protein bar.

Sounds like Mr. Jones is trying to justify to himself and to others why unequal pay for women still exist ubiquitously. To tell an intelligent woman that 'every single idea' she has regarding business will be trumped by the gravitational pull of her motherly bond is absurd. Here's my advice to men like Mr. Jones: Don't talk about uterus-related topics as if you are an expert when the reality is -you don't have a uterus...
reas theslasher14 below for a great answer to this question. You do it ot only to protect yourself but others.  I might add that the motives of witch hunters are not pure.

Some of the same problems here. I did know Elinor WYLIE, but JACK KIRBY and LIANE Balaban were complete mysteries.

Glad you liked the cluing for SOAR. Please explain it to me.

A tribute to Worrum R. Drawde? Wohs tnellecxe!

The bottom third came together quite easily, followed by the North. The ALOE - OLEO crossing in the NW looked odd, and EGGY-NAGGY in the SW was buggy (eggy-noggy would've been better), but in the scheme of things, the WOLF DNA theme was worth it.

However, I found the central section unattractive. I never heard of JACK KIRBY, Elinor WYLIE or Miss Balaban, so these pockets may have as well been clued "your best guess here" or "Lat. abbr." I guessed right with WYLIE, with JACK I had no idea except for the J from JEANNIE. Was Ms. Balaban named after a tropical vine? Grateful for LOS LOBOS. For CHE, not so much. Natick city, but I muddled through.

Favorite clue: Triple, quadruple or more for SOAR (with Triple-SEC: a double-triple).

It was tougher than I expected for Thursday, but the satisfaction was sweeter once finished.

Readable column at 8D: ROBOTS TEND TOT - The shape of things to come?

Terrific Thursday, Julian.

Good night.

JB, I understand some. I am Tired with a capital T of all the apologists for middle east reactionary politics, because, we are the evil empire. I really wish there were a simpler solution for the worlds' need to buy oil and the inability for an entire religion 1.5 billion to get over 6 million Jews living on a sliver of land in their fiefdom. Without that need for oil there would not be a need for this discussion. The middle east would instead have what? What would the world want from them? How would Iran and the middle east finance itself?
Thank you for saving me from writing this less sucsinctly.
I wish they'd hurry up. I don't know how much more of this the country can take.
We can hope the GOP is going off a cliff by itself, and does not take the rest of us with it.

There are many reasons to believe (too many to recount here) that the Republican party is driving off a cliff like Thelma and Louise. It's too bad Bachmann won't be along for that long, last wonderful ride. Yet, she deserves rich credit for having helped the process along. Three cheers.

I think people evolved as tribal creatures. It was necessary to belong to a tribe for food, for comfort, for protection. Collectively people can come to imagine things that as individuals they would not be able to believe. To question the collective religion is to face the threat of isolation. The deeper the question, the greater the threat, the more vigorous the rejection.
There's a very simple reason for equity to support management, which is that they have achieved incredible returns.  It's quite simple really.
It would be informative to have a list of institutional shareholders that also depend on JPM for business, such as employee benefit plans, who might have other reasons to support management.

Thanks for taking our licks for us, Deb.

I started with the south because I know there's sometimes a reveal there, but I got stuck on a lot of the nontheme entries. End of story, it took me almost as much time to solve this puzzle as I expect to spend on a Friday.

I do not like the word NAGGY. I do not appreciate crossing JACK with KIRBY, and the only Balaban I ever heard of was Bob. And his dad I guess. TOT was cute as were ROBOTS. Nice to see LOS LOBOS and OMAR EPPS. I have seen every House episode he appeared in.

On to the Weekenders!

John, Congratulations galore to you and your Chicago Blackhawks on their tremendous victory in O.T. against their long time division rivals, the Detroit Redwings...The Second City must be rocking tonight!

Howie
*affordable education
Unfortunately, not everyone was born to be educated, affordable or not.
OK, then you go ahead and inform nearly every employer that college degrees are no longer a requirement.

My solutions to the dilemma of a two-tier society are as follows:

Education, education and more education followed by a tax on corporations who saddle us with the social displacement costs when jobs are shifted overseas.
Jones, it's for omnivores in transition to vegetarian foods.  It also informs the eater what it resembles.

Gabrielle - you must be very young and/or naive. Those of us who have been living a long while know that humans tend to love and cherish animals more than other humans.  Usually for good reason.  As insensitive as humans tend to be towards the suffering of other humans, the evil they inflict on other "sentient beings" through factory farming is shocking, sad, and deserving of condemnation.
Kudos for being a vegetarian.  I am, too, but I eat far too much cheese.  From a nutrition standpoint, it is deadly stuff.

Liz Dickson, you're taking the right steps.  Baby steps are easy and human health and the planet's health will both improve. Reducing meat consumption by Americans  will do more for the environment than reducing driving or buying an electric or hybrid car. We don't buy cars every day, but we eat every day. Reducing your mileage 20 miles a day will not have as much effect on the environment as cutting red meat consumption by 25%/day.

"Humanely raised", "organic", "pasture raised" are just buzzed words created by the industry to make you feel better about what is essentially a unethical or morally problematic endeavor; slaughtering another individual to please your palate. Even nonhuman animals raised on the most "ethical" of farms are castrated, branded, artificially inseminated, have their children removed from them and turned into veal or sold as suckling pigs. Do you really have the nerve to call these practices humane?

I'll take self-righteousness and ignorance any day over the sadistic practices factory farming.  I'm a vegetarian, and agree with Albert Einstein that a vegetarian diet is the surest way to ensure the survival of the planet.  I don't tell ANYONE what to eat, though, and believe in free markets.  Education is the key, and this thoughtful article is a start.
